@graph.name: Fortran for High Performance Computing
@graph.description: Despite its age, Fortran remains the dominant programming language for high performance computing. This webinar will discuss language constructs that are pertinent to HPC such as coarrays, do concurrent, and improved interoperability with C in the 2018 standard. This webinar will also discuss GPU programming in CUDA and OpenACC as well as the MPI 2018 bindings that use derived data types. The webinar will discuss recent attempts to revive Fortran and encourage the community to be more involved in the future of the language via the new website.

@graph.name: ONLINE Numerical methods for Large Eddy Simulation
@graph.description: The AVBP code is a parallel code of fluid mechanics that solves compressible Navier-Stokes equations for laminar and turbulent reactive flows, in 2D and 3D, on unstructured and hybrid meshes, with third order Taylor Galerkin schemes. The resolution of these equations is based on the Large Eddy Simulation (or Large Eddy Simulation) approach. Reduced chemical kinetics according to the Arrhenius law coupled to the TFLES model for sub-grid flame-turbulence interactions make possible to treat combustion phenomena. AVBP can also calculate two-phase flows using a Lagrangian or Eulerian solver. AVBP applies to aeronautical combustion chambers, turbomachinery, industrial furnaces and safety issues, it allows for example to evaluate polluting emissions (CO, NOx and soot), to treat thermo-acoustic instabilities or detonation phenomena. AVBP is a world-famous code in the field of combustion, used by many laboratories (IMFT in Toulouse, EM2C in Centralesupelec, TU Munich, Von Karmann Institute, ETH Zurich, etc.) and in industry (SAFRAN AIRCRAFT ENGINES, SAFRAN HELICOPTER ENGINES, ARIANEGROUP, HERAKLES, TOTAL, etc.).

@graph.name: Data analytics for engineering data using machine learning
@graph.description:
As part of the EXCELLERAT training program, Fraunhofer SCAI offers a workshop on data analytics for engineering data using machine learning.

The workshop day consists of two parts:

  1. In the morning part an introductory training on machine learning topics like clustering and dimension reduction techniques is provided. Brief hands-on exercises in python will aid the understanding of the material. 
  2. The second part will take place in the afternoon and will specifically deal with applying the machine learning methods from the first part to numerical simulation data stemming from engineering tasks. The SCAI DataViewer will assist the participants in analysing the provided simulation data sets. 



This first instance of this workshop will be open for all partners and corresponding institutes of EXCELLERAT.
